p.s: Sonnet 60 written by Shakespeare is a sonnet with three quatrinsquatrains and a doublet.
Sonnet 60 is about describing the fading beauty of a loved person getting old with the beauty of nature.
The first quatrinquatrain is about the natural cycle of life.
A metaphor for that is the waves, it describes the life span as well because it stands for your time running up.
The hard work shown is the 4th verse describes your life and daily work brings you to your last battle, this is a metaphor for your death that comes closer everydayevery day.
The second quatrinquatrain is about the birth of the individual person.
Every person only sees the light for a first time once.
The second verse is about the maturing of the people and the changes they make and being crowned afterwards.
This is a metaphor for being rewarded.
The crooked eclipses in the third phrase are a metaphor for all the dark times in life that try to make his glory fight which means his life harder.
The last verse in this quatrinquatrain is about the susprisingsurprising gift he gets for making it through all those hard times.
The third and final quatrinquatrain is about the fading beauty of a loved one symbolised by the nature.
In verse one the fading of beauty is symbolized by the flourish set of youth, this describes that the beauty fades by time just like in the nature.
The second verse in this quatrinquatrain is about searching the parallels of the beauty while fading.

The last two verses in this quatrinquatrain are about the rarities and specialitysspecialities in life and nature and that in the end there isnot very much left in life and that the beauty always fades.
The doublet is about Shakespeare hoping that this sonnet will last long and that he hopes that the beloved one sees that he praises his worth.
